title.value: Implementing automation in deep brain stimulation: has the time come?
title.justification: The title is clearly mentioned at the beginning of the document.
title.quote: Implementing automation in deep brain stimulation: has the time come?

extractions.description: The paper evaluates a data-driven model for automated deep brain stimulation (DBS) parameter setting to improve motor symptoms control while considering stimulation-induced side-effects. It discusses the potential of computational models and algorithm-driven optimization in DBS programming and the need for future research to enhance the precision and applicability of these methods.

type.justification: The paper is based on experimental results and prospective, randomised and double-blind clinical trials.
type.quote: Jan Roediger and colleagues present the results of a prospective, randomised, double-blind, crossover clinical trial assessing the therapeutic benefit of deep brain stimulation (DBS) settings derived from individual neuroimaging metrics.

name.justification: The study focuses on neuromodulation techniques, specifically through deep brain stimulation for neurological disorders.
name.quote: If the future of neuromodulation is high-density neural interfaces, offline optimisation might be the only option.

name.justification: The entire study revolves around optimizing the parameters and improving the outcomes of Deep Brain Stimulation.
name.quote: The work from Roediger and colleagues positions itself radically in the forecasting area, whereby most of the therapeutic decision making around DBS parameter setting could be performed by offline simulation.

name.justification: The paper discusses computational models to predict and optimize DBS settings.
name.quote: Computational models of stimulation efficacy are built by linking models of neuronal activation to cohort data to forecast what stimulation patterns are the most likely to be optimal.

name.justification: The VTA model is explicitly mentioned as part of the computational modeling approach to predict stimulation outcomes.
name.quote: Computational models of stimulation efficacy are built by linking models of neuronal activation (eg, volume of tissue activated, VTA) to cohort data.

is_contributed.justification: The VTA model is a referenced model and not unique to this study.
is_contributed.quote: The forecasting approach to DBS programming is founded on an adaptation of the imperfect VTA model.

is_executed.justification: The VTA model was used as a foundational aspect of the forecasting approach to DBS programming in this study.
is_executed.quote: The forecasting approach to DBS programming is founded on an adaptation of the imperfect VTA model.

is_compared.justification: The VTA model is not compared with other models within this paper.
is_compared.quote: The forecasting approach to DBS programming is founded on an adaptation of the imperfect VTA model.

referenced_paper_title.value: Automated deep brain stimulation programming based on electrode location: a randomised, crossover trial using a data-driven algorithm
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced work by Roediger and colleagues uses the VTA model.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Roediger J, Dembek TA, Achtzehn J, et al. Automated deep brain stimulation programming based on electrode location: a randomised, crossover trial using a data-driven algorithm.

name.justification: The dataset is mentioned in relation to training the algorithm for DBS programming.
name.quote: The algorithm was trained on a monocentric dataset, did not include targets other than the subthalamic nucleus.

referenced_paper_title.value: Automated deep brain stimulation programming based on electrode location: a randomised, crossover trial using a data-driven algorithm
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced work is focused on the dataset used for the algorithm training.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Roediger J, Dembek TA, Achtzehn J, et al. Automated deep brain stimulation programming based on electrode location: a randomised, crossover trial using a data-driven algorithm.
